sense.name: a gradual process of deterioration, ruin
sense.commentary: DECAY[+process][+gradual][+deterioration][+physical/+social] Note: can be a nominalization - the decay of his teeth -> his teeth decayed
sense.examples: Fluoride is supposed to help prevent the decay of teeth. (refers to the process) The preacher warned of the moral decay threatening our youth. The ancient temple was in an advanced state of decay when they discovered it.

sense.name: gradual decrease in the strength of a signal
sense.commentary: DECAY[+process][+gradual][+decrease][+strength][+signal] Note: refers to a dying away of a signal, e.g., acoustic or electromagnetic
sense.examples: The decay of acoustic signals is proportional to the inverse of the distance squared. This electric current exhibits an exponential decay. (decreasing in power)

sense.name: organic rot
sense.commentary: DECAY[+entity][+organic][+rot] Note: refers to actual instance of rotten things, -not- the process of deterioration.
sense.examples: The new plants were nourished by the layer of decay on top of them. The dentist removed a pocket of decay from John's molar. The corpses on the battlefield had become a biohazard of decay and disease.

sense.name: gradual radioactive disintegration of atomic nuclei
sense.examples: The half-life of carbon-14's decay makes it useful to determine the age of fossils. They detected the emission of alpha particles during radioactive decay of the isotope. The was a beta decay problem on the nuclear engineering midterm exam.
